item.title: Report E-2025020092
item.description:
Report E-2025020092

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-10T06:19:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-07
  • City: MANCHESTER
  • State: NH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 7, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of printing ink was punctured and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Republic Services (RS) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the site. RS personnel dismantled the impacted pallet as well. All waste was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The damaged drum was containerized in one (1) 85-gallon drum.

item.description:
Report E-2025020088

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-10T06:19:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-06
  • City: DANVILLE
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 6, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of paint released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Indiana Spill Response (ISR) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the sites and containerized all impacted materials in two (2) 55-gallon drums. The damaged drum of product was overpacked in one (1) 85-gallon drum.

  • Description: Package was found to be wet durning AM Sort. When the package was inspected they realize it had a stronge odor of fuel and this could be an undeclared DG package. The DG again then called DG Admin and was advised to hold the package for it being an undeclared. It was discovered after talking with receipent that this was an Air Craft part and it was most likely jet fuel that was leaking from this part. The package is being held.

item.title: Report E-2025020096
item.description:
Report E-2025020096

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-10T06:19:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-05
  • City: COLOGNE
  • State:
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN COLOGNE, GERMANY, ONE AIR PACKAGE FROM USA TO GERMANY WAS FOUND SOILED WITH A VERY STRONG ODOR. THE PACKAGE HAS AN EXCEPTED QUANTITY MARK APPLIED TO THE PACKAGE WITH CLASSES INDICATED AS 3, 4.1, 6.1, 8, AND 9. CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS MULTIPLE GLASS BOTTLES INSIDE WITH SEVERAL SHATTERED AND LEAKING. SEVEN GLASS BOTTLES ARE 500 ML SIZE EACH. SIXTEEN GLASS BOTTLES ARE 30 ML EACH. THE REGULATED CONTENTS INSIDE THE BOX ARE EXCEPTED QUANTITIES OF MATERIALS CLASSIFIED AS UN2874, FURFURYL ALCOHOL, 6.1, PG III, UN3265 CORROSIVE LIQUID ACIDIC ORGANOS NOS, CLASS 8, PG III, UN1224 KETONES LIQUID NOS, CLASS 3, PG III, UN1325 FLAMMABLE SOLIDS ORGANIC NOS, CLASS 4.1, PG III, AND UN1197 EXTRACTS FLAVORING LIQUID, CLASS 3, PG II. THERE ARE ADDITIONAL CHEMICALS INSIDE THE BOX THAT ARE NOT REGULATED IN TRANSPORTATION. THE PACKAGE AND CONTENTS WILL BE DISPOSED OF.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On February 3, 2025, one (1) 330-gallon tote of phosphoric acid was punctured and released approximately 330-gallons of product to the asphalt pavement and nearby storm drain. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel noted that the product released into a storm drain onsite and began utilizing a vacuum trailer to remove the liquids at each storm drain between the terminal building and the retention pond. All acid impacted liquids were collected and containerized into three (3) 330-gallon totes and one (1) 275-gallon tote and staged onsite for further management.

item.title: Report I-2025010054
item.description:
Report I-2025010054

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-10T00:57:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-30
  • City: PORTLAND
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: ALASKA AIRLINES, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Pax had spare lithium battery inside a pouch filled with pens and stickers. According to FA battery started to smoke and release a funky smell. Open opening they noticed that a camera battery had started expanding. Battery melt and charred some of the things that was around it. Appears one of the 3 batteries inside pouch started to smoke. It did char and melt some of the surrounding items. Was put inside BCB. After a thorough debrief with the flight attendants and the passenger involved, it appears the passenger was attempting to improvise a point-and-shopt style camera battery with wires and electrical tape to charge her iPod. Our passenger(seated in 32A) with the battery problem alerted the FA B & C after she noticed smoke and an electrical smell coming from the small fabric purse they were in. She reportedly leapt over her seat mates with the bag and brought it back to the aft galley and said something to the effect of "l have a battery fire in my bag." According to the flight attendants, the small amount of smoke and fumes that were present in the cabin quickly dissipated. 15 photos sent to FAA hazmat.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-Logistics contacted ERTS regarding damaged plastic bags of hazardous product, ABF-004. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimated 1lb release from two bags onto the wooden trailer floor in a 4’ x 4’ area and the concrete dock floor in a 2’x2’ area as a result of improper loading. The contractor cleaned-up the release using a HEPA vac. Two 55-gallon DF’s containing the damaged bags of product, impacted PPE, and impacted plastic were generated for waste disposal. XPO will manage all waste created from the spill response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

item.title: Report E-2025020080
item.description:
Report E-2025020080

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-04
  • City: KARLSRUHE-GROTZ
  • State:
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE KARLSRUHE CENTER IN GERMANY ONE FULLY DECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS PACKAGE ARRIVED WITH EVIDENCE OF HAVNG UNDERGONE A PREVIOUS LITHIUM BATTERY THERMAL EVENT. THE OUTER BOX HAS SEVERAL VISIBLE PUNCTURE HOLES WITH EVIDENCE OF CHARRING. AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY THE PACKAGE WAS NOT WARM AND WAS NOT IN AN ACTIVE THERMAL EVENT. UPON CONTENT INSPECTION, TWO LITHIUM ION BATTERIES HAVE A BURN APPEARANCE ON THEIR METAL POLES WITH SLIGHT CHARRING AROUND THE POLES. THE LITHIUM-ION BATTERY POLES HAVE PUNCTURED THROUGH TO THE OUTER BOX. THE OUTER BOX IS UN SPECIFICAITON PACKAGING 4G/Y30/S/24/SGP/SCL 033. THE OUTER BOX HAS APPROPRIATE DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS AND LABELS WITH A DANGEROUS GOODS UPS ACCEPTED STICKER HAVING PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACILITY IN HONG KONG. A TELEPHONE REPORT WAS VERBALLY MADE TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AS REQUIRED PER 171.15 ON 05-FEBRUARY-2025 UNDER NRC 1422799.

One PAIL was damaged as a result of improper loading releasing its entire contents. The contractor neutralized and cleaned the release using water and absorbents. One 55-gallon DF was generated containing the damaged pail of product, granular absorbents, shrink wrap, and pallet pieces. XPO will manage all the waste generated from the response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this release.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On January 31, 2025 a package was found during the PM sort that had started emitting smoke and heat. The package contained UN3480, Lithium Ion Batteries, 9. The package was immediately doused with water and an extinguisher was used to put out the flames and stop the evolution of heat, preventing more thermal runaway. The package was then isolated and is being held. FedEx Dangerous Goods Administration attempted to follow the process and report this to the NRC, however the person at the NRC, Mr. Archibald, who answered the call refused to take the report due to the incident not happening on an aircraft or American soil.

  • Description: A FULLY LABELED HAZMAT THAT APPEARED TO BE LEAKING WAS DISCOVERED BY AN UNLOADER IN UNLOAD B. THE UNLOADER LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR. WITHIN 4 MINUTES A DMP RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE CORRECT PPE WITH A FULLY STOCKED SPILL CART. USING THE DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PACKAGE COULD BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE CAPS ON EACH OF THE INNER 1 GALLON PLASTIC CONTAINERS WAS LOOSE BY 1/4 OF A TURN AND 6 OUNCES OF LIQUID HAD LEAKED OUT ONTO THE OUTER CARTON.

THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

THE INNER BOX HOLDING THE BATTERY DOES INDICATE CONTENTS AS D5100R 12V AGM POWERCELL SEALED NON-SPILLABLE LEAD ACID BATTERY.   • Description: THE PACKAGE WAS PALED AND SORTED TO THE NORTH SORT AISLE. THERE, THE SORTER, NOTICED THE PACKAGE WAS LEAKING. SHE LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HER SUPERVISOR. THE SUPERVISOR THEN CALLED FOR A DESIGNATED RESPONDER. THE RESPONDER, FOLLOWING THE DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET, PLACED THE PACKAGE IN A LINED SPILL TUBE. THE EQUIPMENT WAS DECONTAMINATED FOLLOWING THE DECONTAMINATION CHECKLIST. THE PACKAGE WAS THEN TAKEN TO THE DMP AREA FOR FURTHER PROCESSING. IT WAS THERE THE PACKAGE WAS DISCOVERED TO BE AN UNDECLARED HAZMAT. AEROSOLS, FLAMMABLE. INNER BOX MARKED WITH LTD QTY MARKING

item.description:
Report E-2025020038

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-09
  • City: SAINT LOUIS
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 0830 ET, XPO-XSL notified ERTS of a cargo release. It was reported that approximately 1 pint of Express alkali released from a plastic tote due to improper loading The release impacted inside trailer#. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined contractors' assistance would be necessary due to its haz class 8 corrosive and a tote Transfer. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of UN1824 Express Alkali product released to a 28’ x 8’ area of the trailer floor due to a pallet of metal beams had tipped over and punctured the side of the tote. The crew performed a tote transfer and cleaned the impacted trailer floor using Simple Green, granular absorbent pads. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized along with impacted absorbents into (2) 55- gallon poly drums, (2) 55 poly drum contains oil dri, (1) 55-poly drum contains product only. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: While seated, the passenger in 20A went to the back and told the FAs that her phone smelled. The flight attendants then went to 20A, where they could smell something burning. No flames or smoke were seen. No passengers around or flight attendants reported irritation or feeling sick. The flight attendants reported that the charging brick and charging cable were warm and smelled like something was burning. The phone was turned off, and the charger was unplugged from the outlet immediately. Once it was unplugged, the smell went away. The flight attendants also said the passenger's phone would not charge and that the charging cable was damaged but had no exposed wires. Item placed in TCB for remainder of flight.

item.title: Report E-2025010097
item.description:
Report E-2025010097

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • City: SPARTANBURG
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 01/08/2025, at 1215 hours, personnel in the CSXT Spartanburg Yard discovered CELX 206, a loaded tank car of Ethylene, refrigerated liquid, leaking from the top of the tank car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Celanese, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-01-08-00139. HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found that the internal pressure of the tank car was at 74 psi and intermittingly venting. Marion Environmental Inc was additionally dispatched to the scene to conduct a flaring operation to reduce internal pressure off from the tank car. The vacuum was obtained from CELX 206 with a reading of 1300-1500 microns which is an indication that the tank car was over pressurizing. The excess pressure was flared off to 46 psi. CELX 206 was then moved to Celanese industry in Enoree SC without any further issues. The issue was identified, and corrective actions, were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Sam Adkins, 304-638-3138).

It was reported that due to improper packaging, approximately 1 gallon of Sodium Hydroxide - Nu-Brite Cleaner (hazardous - UN3266) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the trailer floor at dock door #85. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of UN3266 Sodium Hydroxide product released to a 6’ x 6’ area of the trailer floor and a 4’x4’ area on the wall of the trailer due to the cap of the tote popping off. The top was replaced, and it was ensured it was seated properly. Sodium Bicarbonate solution was used to neutralize the impacted areas. Contractors containerized impacted rags, PPE and poly sheeting into (1) 55-gallon poly. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report I-2025010018
item.description:
Report I-2025010018

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-11
  • City: DANDRIDGE
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Medical Delivery Services
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 11 :00 am ET on December 11, PETNET Knoxville-UT was notified that an MDS courier transporting three PETNET cases containing live patient doses had been involved in a single-vehicle rollover accident on eastbound Interstate 40 near mile marker 424. The bills of lading for those packages are in Attachment 1. The cases contained a total of five patient doses with a combined activity of approximately 210 mCi of Flourine-18 at the time of the accident, and were being delivered to Haywood Regional Medical Center in Clyde, NC. Although the delivery vehicle appeared to have rolled over several times, no cases were ejected. However, a hazmat team responded to the scene and closed the eastbound lanes of the interstate for several hours. Corporate Health Physicist Chris Walters made phone contact with Chief Lee Turner, who was on the scene of the accident, at approximately 11 :40 am to assess the situation. As a result of that conversation, he requested an on-site visit from the corporate Radiation Protection team. Chief Turner relayed that he had also alerted the TN Division of Radiological Health. At approximately 1:00 PM, Corporate Radiation Safety Officer Elizabeth Gillenwalters and Health Physicist Chris Hile arrived at the scene of the accident. Using a Ludlum 44-9 pancake probe with a Model 3 Meter and a Ludlum 26-1 Integrated Frisker, very careful surveys of the vehicle, one officer's clothing that had been reported as possibly contaminated, and the surrounding area were performed. No results greater than background were identified in any areas or materials surveyed. The officer's clothing items were left at the scene. All three delivery cases were still intact with the security zip tie still in place. Each case was thoroughly wiped on the outside, and the wipes surveyed with the Ludlum 26-1 Integrated Frisker. No results greater than background were identified, verifying no material had left containment. The cases were loaded into our vehicle and returned them to the PETNET UT Knoxville facility, located within the UT Medical Center. Additional photos of the packages and the scene are included in Attachments 2 and 3, respectively.

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver had been making propane deliveries during the remnants of Hurricane Helene. Weather conditions were rainy with very high gusty winds. Driver stated that heavy wind gust caught the truck and pushed the truck toward the shoulder of the roadway. Right side tires dropped off the asphalt and when the driver corrected truck proceeded to overturn in the roadway and rolled coming to a stop on its side. Impact from the rollover damage one of the vapor return valves on the back of the truck and it started leaking propane. Area was secured when law enforcement arrived at the scene. Roadway was closed due to leaking propane. Fire Department and Greenville TN Hazmat team also responded to the site. Response team connected a vapor hose to the truck and routed it away from the truck so that vapor could be flared off to reduce the vapor pressure in the tank. Once the vapor pressure the was reduced the leak subsequently stopped so that the truck could be returned to its wheels and towed from the site.

item.title: Report E-2024120067
item.description:
Report E-2024120067

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-06T00:41:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-05
  • City: KENDALL
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AmeriGas Propane LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 91217
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AmeriGas cargo tank vehicle (bobtail) was traveling west on Roosevelt Highway in Kendell, NY. A 3rd party motorcycle entered the roadway at an intersection directly in front the AmeriGas vehicle. The AmeriGas vehicle did not have a stop sign and had the right of way. The motorcycle entering the intersection had a stop sign from the side road. The AmeriGas vehicle swerved left into the east bound lane to avoid impact with the motorcycle. As the AmeriGas vehicle swerved to the left, the left side wheel left the roadway which led the vehicle into an oncoming tree. The AmeriGas vehicle impacted the tree head-on with the left front corner of the vehicle. Subsequently, the vehicle spun around and rolled over 360 degrees across the roadway, coming to rest back on the wheels. The rollover damaged the rear deck of the vehicle which resulted in breaking a vapor return pipe off at the cargo tank. Propane vapor was released from the cargo tank through the vapor piping connection port. The port had a back check valve installed but it did not set due to damage from the impact. Emergency responders (fire company personnel) ultimately were able to stop the leakage by tapping and manipulating the back check valve to make it set. The driver of the AmeriGas vehicle suffered injuries in the cab of the truck during the rollover and was hospitalized. The 3rd party motorcyclist fled the scene.

  • Description: On January 31, 2025, four (4) 1-gallon pails of paint were damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remove all released material from the trailer. All waste was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-31
  • City: SOUTH BURLINGTON
  • State: VT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package was found on a van line with an exterior stain visible on the cardboard packaging. Upon inspection by QA, it was found that the stain was caused by the contents leaking internally. Three of the four plastic bottles contained in the outer box had loose caps, which allowed their contents to partially spill during transport. There was no sign of damage by dropping, crushing or other mishandling which might have caused the caps to loosen. The leak was confined to the origin package - no other packages were affected, and QA was able to remove the package from the sort before any employees came in contact with the leaking substance.

  • Description: 4 drums of non-regulated material was shipped to Reclaimed Energy on a hazardous waste manifest 0273408676JJK on 1/28/2025. Material was sampled and analyzed per our waste analysis plan. it was found that one drum was hazardous (flash point <140F) and should've shipped as their paint related material waste stream. The manifest was updated to reflect this change. Customer was notified and said one drum was mislabeled prior to shipment. Drum was relabeled for hazardous steam and processed accordingly.

  • Description: On January 27, 2025, one (1) 1-gallon pail of UN1789 was damaged by a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. The crew utilized granular absorbents and hand tools to remove all released material from the dock floor. LSH containerized the damaged pail in one (1) 5-gallon pail and all other debris into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2025010434

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-05T03:26:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-18
  • City: MARKLE
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) gallon of material released from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum due to a forklift accident during unloading that resulted in the drum being punctured. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and gathered the spent material and containerized it into two (2) 5-gallon poly drums. The 55-gallon drum of product was placed in one (1) 85-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: On 1/17/2025 at approximately 0945, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 261690 at the ramp facility in Anchorage, reporting undeclared dangerous goods. The shipment consisted of 2 fiberboard boxes, each containing 201 boxes of safety matches. The shipment was x-rayed and identified by Customs. It appears that the shipment was not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations, as it seems to have shipped without the required markings, labeling, packaging or paperwork. The shipment is being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

  • City: SAN DIEGO

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 1/16/2025 at approximately 1000, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 4835830 at the heavyweight facility in San Diego, reporting a paint spill. The shipment consisted of 10 buckets of paint that were overpacked onto a wooden pallet. The shipment sustained damage due to a forklift incident. 1 of the 10 buckets was punctured, resulting in spillage. The damaged bucket was inverted and placed in a salvage drum for disposal. The remaining pieces of the shipment will continue forward in transit upon receipt of an amended Shipper's Declaration of Dangerous Goods.

  • Description: Upon inspection of the vehicle by a state inspector it was brought to the driver's attention that the tank was leaking, and the driver was directed to place a bucket below the leak, which he did. The incident was observed at the final destination facility prior to unloading. The driver moved the vehicle to the unloading location and unloaded the waste without further incident. The cause of leak was believed to be debris lodged between the door gasket and mating surface allowing liquid to leak out. Subsequent inspection showed no evidence of damage.
